Absolute continuity of motion is not comprehensible to the human mind.
Laws of motion become comprehensible to man only when he examines arbitrarily selected elements of that motion.
A large proportion of human error comes from the arbitrary division of continuous motion into discontinuous elements.
There is a well-known sophism of the ancients that Achilles could never catch up with a tortoise he was following.
Achilles traveled ten times as fast as the tortoise.
By the time Achilles covered the distance that separated him from the tortoise, the tortoise had covered one tenth of that distance ahead of him.
When Achilles covered that tenth, the tortoise had covered another one hundredth.
This continues forever.
The problem seemed insoluble to the ancients.
The absurd answer that Achilles could never overtake the tortoise resulted from the arbitrary division of motion into discontinuous elements.
The motion of Achilles was continuous.
The motion of the tortoise was continuous.
By adopting smaller and smaller elements of motion, we only approach a solution of the problem.
We never reach a complete solution of the problem by adopting smaller elements.
Only when we have admitted the conception of the infinitely small do we reach a solution of the problem.
The resulting geometrical progression has a common ratio of one tenth.
The sum of this progression to infinity is found.
A modern branch of mathematics has achieved the art of dealing with the infinitely small.
It can now yield solutions in other more complex problems of motion which used to appear insoluble.
This modern branch of mathematics admits the conception of the infinitely small.
It conforms to the chief condition of motion (absolute continuity).
It corrects the inevitable error which the human mind cannot avoid when it deals with separate elements of motion instead of examining continuous motion.
